challengeName: Apollo Meeting Room Occupancy (MRO) Hardware Challenge
detailedRequirements:
Overview:
 
Welcome to the Apollo Meeting Room Occupancy (MRO) Hardware Challenge. We recently created an ideation challenge on this same topic. Thanks to the creativity of the community, we got some great ideas back! In this challenge we’re looking to take things to a deeper level. We’d like to get a detailed technical plan on how the concept described below could be implemented in the real world.
 
The Problem:
 
Meeting room availability and utilization is often an issue within large companies so we are exploring ideas and concepts that might help provide for improved management.
Currently there is no way of determining meeting room occupancy other than reviewing the meeting room booking system or physically reviewing the office space availability. While the current mechanism works, it has limitations:
  • Meeting rooms are booked for a period of time and often that time is not fully utilized (sub utilization)
  • Meeting rooms are booked but cancelled at late notice without letting the meeting room team know (empty booked rooms)
  • Meeting rooms are under or over populated for the size of the room booked (room efficiency)
  • Physically checking the room is time consuming (room monitoring)
 
Initial Thoughts:
 
The Meeting Room Occupancy (MRO) concept explores the idea of using connected devices and sensors that would monitor for movement and activity within a meeting room, and provide a dashboard to the meeting room administration team. This would allow the room booking team to:
  • Understand whether booked meeting rooms where currently active or inactive
  • Understand whether meeting rooms were being used that had not been booked
  • Generate data that would allow further analysis of meeting room usage (for example, booked meeting room activity vs actual activity, space utilization, sizing of room for booking, etc)
 
Technology Thoughts:
 
As part of a previous ideation challenge, a number of interesting ideas and concepts that explored new technologies were identified as having the potential to address the challenge brief.
  • Devices (i.e. some kind of sensor capability) would be installed into meeting rooms
  • Devices would report activity within their deployment area, and provide data that the device supports for the objectives (see below)
  • Devices would need to be respectful of the office environment: ergonomics and aesthetics
  • A dashboard would be used by the meeting room admin team to monitor activity in meeting rooms
 
What is specifically NOT of interest in this challenge, is the elements of the end user (meeting room administrator) application and user interfaces.
 
 
Technology devices:
  • Meeting Room sensor camera(s) that are able to detect entry and exit events - http://blogs.wcode.org/2015/04/footfall-a-camera-based-people-counting-system-for-under-60/
  • Passive Infrared presence detection sensors
  • Wide angle, discrete video feeds (camera) with software that do some kind of detection in real time : movement, faces, people
  • Video post processing: video feeds from meeting rooms that are batch processed
  • Sensor enabled flooring (smart carpets) that can be placed within a meeting room space - http://future-shape.com/download/42/Flyer+SensFloor+sensor+floor.pdf
  • Ceiling mounted thermal sensors - Omron D6T 44L-06, Panasonic AMG8832 and Melexis MLX90620ESF-BAD.
 
Brief Deliverables
 
We are looking for a deeper dive on a specific solution in this challenge. Please present a single, thoroughly researched solution, utilizing one or more of the technologies above. If you identify additional technologies necessary for your solution, you may include those as well.
  • what sensor data is used
  • how sensor data is combined, and modified to feed into the admin interface
  • focus on the user experience as well as the overall objectives being sought
  • from a room perspective, looking for non invasive experiences
  • looking for reliability of the solution
  • looking for the depth and precision of the solution
 
Your submission should be organized into 4 sections detailed here.
 
1) Name
  • Application or project name and any "tagline" you would like to associate with your idea
 
2) Concept
  • High level overview/statement of the idea with one or two sentences describing your idea.
 
3) The User Story
 
Describe in detail how the overall experience of having this technology implemented in an office environment. What’s happening behind the scenes when meeting participants are in a meeting room, what happens when a room is booked, but no one attends the meeting (the room is empty for some period of time, …etc).
 
4) Details and corroborating research
 
This section should include a detailed technical discussion of your solution:
  • Sketches or designs/images to better explain the experience
  • Details of the technologies used, including why these were chosen and how they meet the specific technology considerations
  • A bill of materials to implement your hardware solution in a single room (specific part numbers and suppliers), with estimated costs. Include details on how this would be expanded for deployment into multiple rooms
  • Details and diagrams of how the different pieces integrate to provide the solution
  • Details on how the “sensing data” will be delivered to the software (software interface is out of scope here, please just described the intended “handoff” of information from your solution)
 
Additional Considerations:
  • From a room perspective, we’re looking for non-invasive experience
  • The solution should be highly reliable
  • Depth and precision – your solution should be accurate in it’s detection
  • Data privacy - collection of data from sensors needs to take into consideration the potential data privacy concerns that might arise from such data
  • Device management, operation, maintenance and security – solution should be simple to administrate and easy to secure
 
 
Judging Criteria
 
This challenge will be scored, by the client, with a custom scorecard (in Direct we will use a simple 1st, 2nd, 3rd scorecard). There will not be community reviewers. We will share detailed scores with you after the challenge closes. Each area of your submission will be scored considering the following criteria (where applicable):
  • Cost of implementing the overall idea will be a consideration and this should include all aspects of the solution and details should be provided to support your solution
  • Feasibility of your idea including what dependencies would be required to meet the overall brief of objectives as well as how easy it is to install, procure and implement
  • User experience/engagement focus.
  • Clarity and presentation - how well is it presented and how easy is it to understand?
  • The quality of your research and the details provided.
 
The 4 Sections of your submission will be judged as follows
  • Section 1 - 2 : 5% each
  • Section 3: 30%
  • Sections 4: 50%
 
In addition, the overall presentation of your submission is important. Imagine trying to sell your idea, present your solution in a professional manner/package. This will count as 10% of your score.
finalSubmissionGuidelines: Your submission should in the form of a Word or PDF document including a detailed recommendation based on the requirements above, along with diagrams, spreadsheets, and other supporting information and documents.
